docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: kache is a modern cloud-native web accelerator and HTTP cache proxy that is highly available, reliable, and performant. It supports the latest RFC specifications and should be able to handle high traffic loads, be easily scalable, and support distributed caching systems.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
You can install and run Kache in the following ways:

  • Use the official Docker image
  • Use the binary distribution
  • Build binary from source
  • Use the Helm Chart

docs.title: Use the Official Docker Image
docs.text:
Use one of the official Docker images and run it with the sample configuration file:

docker run -d -p 8080:8080 -p 80:80 \
    -v $PWD/kache.yml:/etc/kache/kache.yml \
    kache:latest -config.file=/etc/kache/kache.yml

docs.title: Use the binary distribution
docs.text:
To run kache, get the latest binary from the releases page and run it with the sample configuration file:

./kache -config.file=kache.yml

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
If you want to run kache with a distributed caching backend (e.g. Redis), you can use and run this example docker-compose as a starting point:

docker-compose -f cloud/docker-compose.yml up

Tip

Check the Quick Starts for Docker and Kubernetes to learn more.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: The following describes how to run kache on a locally with Docker.

docs.title: Set up a docker-compose
docs.text:
Create and define a docker-compose.yml and define a kache service that uses the official Kache image:

services:
kache:
# Use the `main` tag for the latest development image 
# or `latest` tag for the latest stable version.
image: kacheio/kache:main
container_name: kache
# Start the container with the mounted config file.
command:
- "-config.file=/etc/kache/kache.sample.yml"
# Expose port that are configured in the kache config file.
ports:
- "80:80"
- "8080:8080"
- "1337:1337"
- "1338:1338"
# Mount the config file.
volumes:
- "./../kache.sample.yml:/etc/kache/kache.sample.yml"
# Use redis as distributed remote caching backend.
redis:
image: "redis:alpine"

That's all you need to run Kache with Redis as a distributed caching backend.

docs.title: Run kache
docs.text:
Now start your HTTP cache with the following command:

docker-compose -f cloud/docker/docker-compose.yml up

docs.title: Access kache
docs.text: You can now start browsing http://localhost:8080/ and access Kache's API and get all the keys from the cache under http://localhost:1338/api/v1/cache/keys.
